projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

IN THREE BOOKS:
TOGETHER WITH HIS REMEDY OF LOVE:

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE RICHARD, EARL OF BURLINGTON.

lg.l: OUR Poet's rules, in ea≈øy numbers, tell
He felt the pa≈ø≈øion he de≈øcribes ≈øo well.
„Äà‚óä„Äâ that ≈øoft art ≈øucce≈øsfully refin'd
Tho' angry Cae≈øar frown'd, the fair were kind.
More ills from love, than tyrants' malice flow;
Jove's thunder ≈øtrikes le≈øs ≈øure than Cupid's bow.
Ovid both felt the pain, and found the ea≈øe;
Phy≈øicians ≈øtudy mo≈øt their own di≈øea≈øe.
The practice of that age in this we try;
Ladies ≈øhould li≈øten then, and lovers lie.
Each thought her own admirer in the right;
To be but faintly rude was criminal,
But to be boldly ≈øo, aton'd for all.
Breeding was bani≈øh'd for the fair one's ≈øake;
The ≈øex ne'er gives, but ≈øuffers ours ≈øhould take.
Advice to you, my Lord, in vain we bring.
The flow'rs ne'er fail to meet the blooming ≈øpring.
Tho' you po≈ø≈øe≈øs all nature's gifts, take care;
Love's queen has charms, but fatal is her ≈ønare.
On all, that godde≈øs her fal≈øe ≈ømiles be≈øtows,
As on the ≈øeas ≈øhe reigns, from whence ≈øhe ro≈øe.
Young Zephyrs ≈øing with fragrant breath, ≈øoft gales
Guide her gay barge, and ≈øwell the ≈øilken falls:
Each ≈øilver wave in beauteous order moves,
Fair as her bo≈øom, gentle as her doves;
But he that once embarks, too ≈øurely finds
A ≈øullen ≈øky, black ≈øtorms, and angry winds.
Cares, fears, and angui≈øh, hov'ring on the coa≈øt,
And wrecks on wretches, by their folly lo≈øt.
When coming time ≈øhall ble≈øs you with a bride,
Let pa≈ø≈øion not per≈øuade, but rea≈øon guide:
In≈øtead of gold, let gentle truth endear:
She has mo≈øt charms, who is the mo≈øt ≈øincere.
Shun vain variety, 'tis but di≈øea≈øe:
Weak appetites are ever hard to plea≈øe.
The nymph mu≈øt fear to be inqui≈øitive:

Still charming with all arts that can engage,
And be the JULIANA of the age.

div.head: INTRODUCTION.
div.p: OVID'S Art of Love, having lately appeared in French with Ob≈øervations written by the tran≈ølator, which have been very well received in France; it has been thought proper to add ≈øuch of them as are mo≈øt curious to this ver≈øion, and to make other new remarks in ≈øome places, where the Engli≈øh tran≈ølators have given another turn to the original. The introduction to the≈øe ob≈øervations is entirely the French author's; ≈øo are mo≈øt of the reflections. 'Tis hop'd tho≈øe that are not taken from him, will not be found to be of le≈øs importance than tho≈øe that are‚ñ™

A great many people are mi≈øtaken in the≈øe books: and though they were made u≈øe of as a pretence to drive the author from the court of Augu≈øtus, and confine him to Tomos, on the frontiers of the Getae and Surmatae, yet they were not the true cau≈øe of his confinement. They are very far from being ≈øo licentious as the writings of ≈øeveral other poets, both Greek and Latin. However, we mu≈øt own he might have been a little more di≈øcreet, e≈øpecially in ≈øome places.

That which offended the Romans mo≈øt in this work, cannot touch us. It has always been more dangerous in Italy to conver≈øe with women of honour, and frequent their hou≈øes, than 'tis with us: Though there is more liberty, and what in that country may be an occa≈øion of debauchery, would not at all be ≈øo in ours.

Notwith≈øtanding all that has been ≈øaid again≈øt the≈øe books of the Art of Love, by ≈øome over-≈øcrupulous per≈øons, who≈øe di≈øcretion has too much of affectation in „Äà‚óä„Äâ ; they are not only nece≈ø≈øary for the knowledge of the Latin tongue, and the Roman hi≈øtory, concerning which they contain ≈øeveral things very particular; but for the noble „Äà‚óä„Äâ we find in them, which the mo≈øt grave and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ have thought worthy to be „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ .

In a word, there's nothing in them that comes near the licence of ≈øome epigrams of Catullus Martial, and Au≈øonius, of ≈øome ≈øatyrs of Horace and Juvenal, and ≈øeveral other pieces of ancient and modern authors which are read and commented upon; and about which even celebrated Je≈øuits and other religious per≈øons, as eminent for their piety as their erudition, have employed their ≈øtudies. Yet who has condemn'd or complain'd of them? We mu≈øt confe≈øs, ≈øuch things ≈øhould be manag'd with addre≈øs: and tho≈øe of them who have meddled with any of the authors I have named, have ≈øhewn that it may be done ≈øo, by their ≈øucceeding ≈øo happily in it.

As for this treati≈øe of the Art of Love, for which the author has al≈øo pre≈øcrib'd a remedy, as it is liable to be all interpreted by tho≈øe who≈øe pens poi≈øon every thing they touch; ≈øo it may bear a good con≈øtruction, by ≈øuch as know how to turn every thing to advantage.

I will yet ≈øay, this Art may be apply'd to tho≈øe that intend to marry. There is nothing ≈øure again≈øt decency in all that. I agree, if you will have it ≈øo, that it extends ≈øo far as to direct one to the means to gain a mi≈øtre≈øs. If this was not lawful heretofore in Italy, on account of the jealous humour of the Italians, we cannot, for the ≈øame rea≈øon only, ≈øay it ought to be forbidden in our country, any more than in ≈øeveral others, provided we could be ≈øure the ladies mode≈øty would not be offended, before whom youth ≈øhould be always careful not to exceed the bounds of the re≈øpect that's due to them.

Be it as it will, I have thought of endeavouring to apply all that is ≈øaid in tho≈øe books of wanton love, to the art of loving the ≈øciences. The emblem is not di≈øagreeable, neither is it impo≈ø≈øible to explain all that Ovid has written here upon the love of beauty by that of the arts. What do we not ≈øometimes under≈øtand by the loves of a ≈øhepherd and ≈øhepherde≈øs? By a lover of incomparable beauty, and his fair one pa≈ø≈øionately in love? But, keeping to the fable, how often has the loves of Jupiter and
Juno been moraliz'd upon, as well as tho≈øe of Apollo and Daphne, Mars and Venus, Myrrha and Cynaras, and ≈øeveral others, the examples of which are almo≈øt infinite? Yet the≈øe things are ≈øeen every day, all the world read and admire them. Tho' the out≈øide of them is a little ≈øtrong, and the literal ≈øen≈øe more ≈øu≈øpected, than any of the precepts laid down in Ovid's Art of Love are licentious.

But, to ≈øoften this thought a little, let us figure to our≈øelves, that the poet is not only a gallant of the court of Augu≈øtus, but a philo≈øopher of the Portic and Lyceum; who propo≈øes to us, as to his di≈øciples, excellent rules to acquire the virtues and ≈øciences, repre≈øented under the name of the mu≈øes, or ladies of various beauty, who may be met with every where, e≈øpecially in great academies, in the ≈øchools, in courts, in walks, and in holy places; figured by cirques, theatres, galleries, portices, and the temples of the Roman deities, where great a≈ø≈øemblies were held. And when we have cho≈øen that which plea≈øes us be≈øt, and is mo≈øt agreeable to our nature; let us endeavour to gain its good graces, and enjoy it, that we may become more wi≈øe, and more virtuous. Thus we may deceive our imagination: and 'twill be ea≈øy for us to make the reading of this treati≈øe, not only plea≈øant, but profitable. We need not then have any ≈øcruple upon us, becau≈øe there is nothing uncha≈øte in the expre≈ø≈øion, though ≈øuch things as are entirely gallant are not neglected; at lea≈øt no farther than mode≈øty and decency requir'd. I will, if I can, explain my thoughts in this matter, according as occa≈øion may offer.

Of the Art of Love. By this we ought to under≈øtand how we mu≈øt love, or how we mu≈øt pre≈øerve the „Äà‚óä„Äâ of our love, when we have once acquir'd it. Otherwi≈øe 'twas u≈øele≈øs to write an Art of love. For love is form'd in the heart without art, and all are without art ≈øu≈øceptible of that pa≈ø≈øion. It generally ≈øurprizes us, and we know not from whence it comes, though we feel it very ≈øen≈øibly. For this rea≈øon the poets ≈øo often endeavour to
per≈øuade us that love is a potent god, who wounds every thing with his darts; and that there is no creature able to re≈øi≈øt him. We therefore need no art to teach us to love, or even to love any thing rea≈øonably; but 'tis of very great importance to each of us, that, when we are in≈øpir'd, the in≈øpiration ≈øhould be for a proper object, and a good end, as I de≈øign to ≈øhew you.

Ovid. This poet wrote the≈øe books a few years before his exile, under colour of which the decree of the ≈øenate for his bani≈øhment was procur'd‚ñ™ though they certainly were not the cau≈øe of it; and indeed could not rea≈øonably be ≈øo, unle≈øs Ovid wrote them in favour of Augu≈øtus's granddaughter, whom he vi≈øited with a little too much familiarity, and did it to plea≈øe her. For ≈øhe, no more than her mother, Agrippa's wife, was not ≈øo mode≈øt as per≈øons of quality and high condition ought to be, as well for their own glory, as for an example to others.

The two fir≈øt books of the Art of Love, contain the precepts which the author lays down for young men to follow in their court≈øhip to the ladies, and the third teaches the ladies how they ought to make them≈øelves belov'd. The allegory is not unea≈øily applied to the ≈øciences and the virtues, repre≈øented as lovely women, after my way of imagining it.

The frequent ≈øighs, and tender murm'ring voice:
To ≈øee her eyes with vary'd plea≈øure move,

Nature's not thus indulgent to the young,
The≈øe joys alone to riper years belong.
Who youth enjoys drinks crude unready wine,

To Helen who'd Hermione prefer?
Or Gorge think beyond her mother fair?
But he that covets the experienc'd dame

One con≈øcious bed receives the happy pair:
Retire, my mu≈øe; the door demands thy care. mm
What charming words, what tender things are ≈øaid!

There ≈øhall the roving hand employment find,

When weary from the field Achilles came,
Thus with delays he rais'd Bri≈øe ‚Ä¢ s' flame.
Ah, could tho≈øe arms, tho≈øe fatal hands delight?

Nor yet with ≈øpeed the fleeting plea≈øure wa≈ø ‚Ä¢ e,
Still moderate your love's impetuous ha≈øte:
The ba≈øhful virgin, tho' appearing coy,
Detains your hand, and hugs the proferr'd joy.
Then view her eyes with humid lu≈øtre bright,

Her kind complaints, her melting accents hear,
The eye ≈øhe charms, and wounds the li≈øt'ning ear.
Defer not then the cla≈øping nymph's embrace,
But with her love maintain an equal pace:
Rai≈øe to her heights the tran≈øports of your ≈øoul,
And fly united to the happy goal,
Ob≈øerve the≈øe precepts when with lei≈øure ble≈øt,
No threat'ning fears your private hours mole≈øt;

Then ply your oars, then practi≈øe this advice.
And ≈øtrain with whip and ≈øpur to gain the prize.
The work's compleat, triumphant palms prepare,
With flow'ry wreaths adorn thy flowing hair.
As to the Greeks was Podalirius' art,
To heal with medicines the afflicted part:
Ne≈øtor's advice, Achilles arms in field,
Automedon for chariot-driving ≈økill'd;
As Calchas could explain the my≈øtic bird, nn
And Telamon could wield the brandi≈øh'd ≈øword:
Such to the town may ‚Ä¢ am'd in≈øtructions prove,
So much I am renown'd for arts of love.
Me ev'ry youth ≈øhall prai≈øe, extol my name,
And o'er the globe diffu≈øe my la≈øting fame.
I arms provide again≈øt the ≈øcornful fair,
Thus Vulcan arm'd Achilles for the war.
Whatever youth ≈øhall with my aid o'ercome,
And lead his Amazon in triumph home; oo
Let him that conquers, and enjoy the dame,
In gratitude for his in≈øtructed flame,
In≈øcribe the ≈øpoils with my au≈øpicious name.
The tender girls my precepts next demand,
Them I commit to a more ≈økilful hand.

And halt, and gaze, and almo≈øt fa≈øten on his fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .
Then fleet away again as ≈øwift as wind,

By this, he ≈øaw his ≈øtrength would ne'er prevail.

From his loo≈øe robe a golden apple drawn,

Now near the goal, he ≈øummons all his might,

Tho' ≈øure to lo≈øe, if ≈øhe the race declin'd,

Pleas'd that ≈øhe lo≈øt, to the glad victor's arms
She gives the prize, and yields her dear-bought charms;

Po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of that, he could not but ≈øubdue,

Yet oh! thou be≈øt belov'd, thou lovelie≈øt maid,
Be not by too much avarice betray'd.
Prize thy≈øelf high, no ea≈øy purcha≈øe prove,
Nor let a fool with fortune buy thy love.
Like Atalanta's conqu'ror let him be,
Brave, gen'rous, young, from every ‚Ä¢ ailing free,
And to compleat him, let him love like me.
What pains again≈øt thy wretched life I take?
Ev'n I my≈øelf my jealou≈øies awake.
Such men there are, ble≈øt with ≈øuch gifts divine,
Who if they knew thee, would be ≈øurely thine.
How wretched then, alas! ≈øhould Daphnis grow?
Gods! know the very thought di≈øtracts him now?
Ev'n now perhaps ≈øome youth with happier charms,

Ev'n now, the favours you deny'd me, ≈øeem
To be too prodigally heap'd on him.
Clo≈øe by your ≈øide, all langui≈øhing he ≈øtands.
And on your panting bo≈øom warms his hands.

Then glows his ravi≈øh'd ≈øoul with pointed flames,
And thoughts of heav'nly joys fill all his dreams.
Let not your pa≈ø≈øion be to me reveal'd,
But if you love, keep him your love conceal'd.

lg.l: FROM Cephalus's tragic ≈øtory, ‚Ä¢ ead

Where plea≈øant valleys breathe a freer air,

By chance I other blandi≈øhments be≈øtow,
Or de≈øtiny decreed it ≈øhould be ≈øo;
As, O thou greate≈øt plea≈øure of the plains,
Thou, who do≈øt nature's riche≈øt ≈øweets excite,
And mak'≈øt me in the de≈øert woods delight:
Breathle≈øs, and dead without thee ≈øhould I be,

While thus I ≈øung, ≈øome one who chanc'd to hear.
Thought her a nymph, to whom I made my pray'r,
And told my Procris of her rival air.
She, kind, good ≈øoul, half dying at the news,
Would now condemn me, now again excu≈øe.
Now hopes 'tis all a fal≈øehood, now ≈øhe fears;
Su≈øpects my faith as I ≈øu≈øpected hers.
Re≈øolv'd, at la≈øt to tru≈øt no bu≈øy tongue,
But be her≈øelf the witne≈øs of her wrong;
When the next day with fatal ha≈øte came on,
And I was to my lov'd diver≈øion gone,
She ro≈øe and ≈øought the ≈øolitary ≈øhade,

Clo≈øe in a thicket undi≈øcern'd ≈øhe ≈øtood,
When I took ≈øhelter in the ≈øhady wood.
Then ≈øtretching on the gra≈øs my fainting weight,
Come much-lov'd air, I cry'd oh! come abate
With thy ≈øweet breath, this mo≈øt immod'rate heat.
On this a ≈øudden noi≈øe invades my ear,
And ru≈øtling boughs ≈øhew'd ≈øomething living there.
I ra≈øhly thinking it ≈øome ≈øavage bea≈øt,
Threw my unerring dart with heedle≈øs ha≈øte,
Which pierc'd, O gods! my Procris thro' the brea≈øt.
She at the wound, with fearful ≈øhrieking fell,

Thither di≈øtracted with my grief I flew,
To give my dying love a ≈øad adieu.
All bloody was her lately ≈ønowy brea≈øt,
Her ≈øoul was ha≈øt'ning to eternal re≈øt.
With rage I tore my robe, which clo≈øe I bound,

What pardons did I beg? what cur≈øes frame,

When weakly rai≈øing up her dying head,
With a faint voice, the≈øe few ≈øad words ≈øhe ≈øaid,
" Draw nearer yet, dear author of my death,
" Hear my la≈øt ≈øighs, and ≈ønatch my parting breath.
" But ere I die, by all that's ≈øacred ≈øwear.
" That you will never let my rival air,

" This I conjure you by your nuptial vow;
" The faith you gave me then, renew me now
" By all your love, if any love remain,

To her ≈øad ≈øpeech abruptly I reply'd,

Quickly I ran the tragic ≈øtory o'er.

That done, ≈øhe rolls, in death her dizzy eyes,

Here did the youth his doleful tale conclude,
A tale too doleful to be long pur≈øu'd.
But this ill-cho≈øen in≈øtance will not do,

But ≈øhe, whene'er I woo ≈øome other fair,

She ≈øees me court another, as unmov'd,
As ≈øhe has always ≈øeen her≈øelf belov'd,
That dreadful thought redoubles all my fear,

No foreign in≈øtance need of this he ≈øh ‚Ä¢ wn,

Tho' of this kind all ages can produce

All day and night I ≈øing, and all day long,

To me, as to the echo, fate affords,

Some glimp≈øe of ≈øun, ≈øome cheerful beams appear,
Ev'n thro' the gloomie≈øt ≈øea≈øon of the year.
My clouded life admits ‚Ä¢ o dawn of light,
No ray can pierce thro' my eternal night.
All there is di≈ømal as the ≈øhades beneath,

My anxious hours roll heavily away,
Depriv'd of ≈øleep by night, and peace by day.
My ≈øoul no re≈øpite form her ≈øuff'rings knows,
And ≈øees no end of her eternal woes.
In a long line they run for ever on,
And ≈øtill increa≈øe, and lengthen as they run.
By flight to lo≈øe my ills in vain I try,
From my de≈øpairing ≈øelf „Äà‚óä„Äâ cannot fly.
Where e'er I go, I bear about my flame,
In cities, countries, ≈øeas, 'tis all the ≈øame.
Scorch'd with my burning pains, I ≈øhun my hou≈øe,
And ≈øtrive in open air to ≈øeek repo≈øe.
My flames, like torches, ≈øhook in open air,

Now to the more retir'd, remote≈øt place,
Ev'n to ob≈øcurity I fly for ea≈øe.
Retirement ≈øtill ≈øoments the raging fire,
And trees, and fields, and floods, and ver≈øe con≈øpire
To ≈øpread the flame and heighten the de≈øire.
Wildly I range the woods, and trace the groves,
To every oak I tell my hopele≈øs loves.
Torn by my pa≈ø≈øion, to the earth I fall,
I kneel to all the gods, I pray to all.
Nothing but echo an≈øwers to my pray'r.
And ≈øhe ≈øpeaks nothing, but de≈øpair, de≈øpair.
From woods and wilds I no relief receive,

Deep thro' the tide, not knowing where, I walk;
To the deaf winds, not knowing what, I talk.
Mad as the foaming main, aloud I rave,
While every tear keeps time with ev'ry wave.

lg.l: A TOW'R with ≈øounding walls erected ≈øtands,

In this unhappy war, and fatal ≈øtrife,

I'd tell the dear di≈øturber of my re≈øt,

All he would a≈øk, all,‚Äîbut my father's crown.

Yet when a „Äà‚óä„Äâ foe di≈øputes the field,

The tragic de≈øt ‚Ä¢ oy of his darling ≈øon,

lg.l: STAY, wretched ≈øwain, lie here, and here lament;

A POETICAL ESSAY.
BY DR. ARMSTRONG.
